title: If the diameter of a circle decreases by 10%, what will be the percentage change in the area of the circle? - Quora

response.answer_text: We all know that area of circle is given by [math]\displaystyle A = \pi {r^2}[/math] [math]\displaystyle A = \frac{{\pi {d^2}}}{4}[/math] If the diameter increases by [math]10\% [/math], we have new diameter as [math]10\% \times d + d[/math] [math]\displaystyle = d\left( {\frac{{10}}{{100}} + 1} \right)[/math] [math] \displaystyle= d\left( {\frac{{110}}{{100}}} \right)[/math] Let the new area be [math]A'[/math]. [math]\displaystyle A' = \frac{\pi }{4}\left( {{d^2} \times {{1.01}^2}} \right)[/math] [math]\displaystyle A' = \frac{\pi }{4}\left( {{d^2} \times {{1.10}^2}} \right)[/math] Now, percentage in the area of circle is given by [math]\displaystyle\frac{{A' - A}}{A} = \frac{{{{1.10}^2}{d^2} - {d^2}}}{{{d^2}}} = \frac{{{d^2}\left( {{{1.10}^2} - 1} \right)}}{{{d^2}}} = \frac{{{\rm{1}}{\rm{.21}} - 1}}{1} = 0.21[/math] [math] \displaystyle\Rightarrow \frac{{A' - A}}{A} \times 100\% = 0.21 \times 100\% = 21\% [/math] Therefore, the percentage in the area of circle is [math]21\% [/math].  Shortcut: If the diameter ( or radius ) of circle increases by [math]d\%[/math], then the percentage change in the area of circle is given by[math] \displaystyle= d + d + \frac{{{d^2}}}{{100}}[/math] [math] \displaystyle= 2d + \frac{{{d^2}}}{{100}}[/math] 2. If the diameter ( or radius ) of circle decreases by [math]d\%[/math], then the percentage change in the area of circle is given by [math]\displaystyle = - d - d + \frac{{{d^2}}}{{100}}[/math] [math]\displaystyle = - 2d + \frac{{{d^2}}}{{100}}[/math]

Use relation : A + B + AB/100 = Net change A = B = -10% Net change ,= -10 - 10 + (-10 x -10)/100 = -19% Negative means decrease in Area. Detailed discussion in this post : K S Narayanan's post in Mathematics Unraveled :-)
